user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_Hook_GetArgPtr:
```c
const void *UT_Hook_GetArgPtr(const UT_StubContext_t *ContextPtr, const char *Name, size_t ExpectedTypeSize)
{
    uint32                      i;
    const void *                Result;
    const UT_StubArgMetaData_t *MetaPtr;

    static const union
    {
        unsigned long AsInt;
        void *        AsPtr;
        double        AsFloat;
    } ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE = {0};

    Result = NULL;
    for (i = 0; i < ContextPtr->ArgCount; ++i)
    {
        MetaPtr = &ContextPtr->Meta[i];
        if (MetaPtr->Name != NULL)
        {
            if (strcmp(MetaPtr->Name, Name) == 0 && (MetaPtr->Size == 0 || MetaPtr->Size == ExpectedTypeSize))
            {
                if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_DIRECT)
                {
                    Result = &ContextPtr->ArgPtr[i];
                }
                else if (MetaPtr->Type == UT_STUBCONTEXT_ARG_TYPE_INDIRECT)
                {
                    Result = ContextPtr->ArgPtr[i];
                }
                break;
            }
        }
    }

    /*
     * If no suitable result pointer was found, this means a mismatch
     * between the stub and test case, such as a change in argument/parameter names.
     * This is an error that should be corrected, so report it as a failure.
     */
    if (Result == NULL)
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("Requested parameter %s of size %lu which was not provided by the stub", Name,
                        (unsigned long)ExpectedTypeSize);

        if (ExpectedTypeSize <= sizeof(ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE))
        {
            Result = &ARG_DEFAULT_ZERO_VALUE;
        }
        else
        {
            /*
             * As the caller will likely dereference the returned pointer, should
             * never return NULL.  Just abort here.
             */
            UtAssert_Abort("No value for parameter");
        }
    }

    return Result;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other parts of the function do not require investigation for MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13 because they already use const-qualified pointee types or do not involve pointer target qualifications. The function return type is const void * (the pointer points to a const-qualified type). The parameter Name is declared as const char * (the pointee is const-qualified). ContextPtr is a pointer to const UT_StubContext_t and MetaPtr is declared as pointer to const UT_StubArgMetaData_t, so accesses via MetaPtr (other than the Name member usage already listed) do not indicate missing const qualification of the pointed-to type. Non-pointer objects (i, AsInt, AsFloat) and logical/size comparisons do not pertain to Rule 8.13. The UtAssert_* calls and the control-flow (loop, break, return) are not relevant to pointer pointee const-qualification. Therefore only the listed fragments (uses/definitions involving non-const pointer targets or pointer members that may be better const-qualified) need further investigation.
